heroIntro: Imagine waking to Mediterranean sunshine in your own private town house, just minutes from pristine Blue Flag beaches and the vibrant pulse of Costa Blanca life. This exceptional 2-bedroom, 2-bathroom town house in Pilar de La Horadada represents the ultimate sunshine retreat for those seeking a holiday home that delivers both style and substance. Priced at €350,000 with premium specifications, you're acquiring a property 40% less expensive than comparable Spanish island markets—a remarkable value proposition in one of Europe's most sought-after coastal regions. Built across 69m² of beautifully appointed living space on a 139m² plot, this residence captures the essence of Mediterranean living without compromise. Whether you envision long, sun-soaked summers with family and friends, or a peaceful winter escape from grey northern skies, this property offers the lifestyle flexibility that holiday home buyers crave. The established expat community here speaks English fluently, making your transition seamless, while the thriving local infrastructure ensures every modern convenience is within reach.
areaSection: Pilar de La Horadada sits on the southern Costa Blanca, positioned between the vibrant beach towns of Torrevieja and Guardamar del Segura. This charming municipality benefits from 320 days of annual sunshine, crystalline Mediterranean waters, and a perfect blend of authentic Spanish culture with international sophistication. The town's geography—perched on the coast with easy access to both sandy beaches and inland pine forests—makes it ideal for those who want seaside relaxation without the overwhelming crowds of busier resorts. The climate here is consistently warm, with mild winters (rarely dropping below 10°C) and hot, dry summers that justify the region's reputation as a year-round destination. Local traditions remain strong, evident in weekly markets and family-run restaurants, yet modern amenities ensure comfort and convenience. The area has experienced steady growth with property appreciation of 8% year-on-year, reflecting both its desirability and the confidence of international buyers who recognize genuine value.
lifestyleSection: Daily life in Pilar de La Horadada unfolds at a relaxed Mediterranean pace, punctuated by excellent beaches, quality dining, and genuine community warmth. The established expat community—particularly British and Northern European residents—means English is widely spoken in shops, restaurants, and professional services, removing common barriers to relocation. Your mornings might begin with a paseo (leisurely walk) along the promenade, followed by coffee at a beachfront café. Mid-week farmers' markets at Mercadona and local markets provide fresh produce and authentic ingredients for Mediterranean cooking. The international community organizes regular social events, sports clubs, and cultural activities, ensuring you're never isolated. Healthcare is reassuringly accessible with English-speaking doctors and private clinics supplementing regional hospital facilities. Evenings bring a choice: fine dining experiences, casual chiringuitos (beach bars) serving fresh seafood, or quiet nights at home watching Mediterranean sunsets. The lifestyle balance here—effortlessly combining relaxation, social connection, and convenience—is precisely what holiday home buyers seek.
investmentSection: This property represents compelling investment logic in a region experiencing sustained growth. Costa Blanca property values have appreciated 8% year-on-year, outpacing general European real estate trends, with Pilar de La Horadada emerging as a particularly attractive value proposition. At €5,072/m², this property commands a premium within the local market (€2,200/m² average), reflecting its superior specifications and desirability—yet remains 40% cheaper than comparable Spanish island properties. Holiday rental potential is significant: typical weekly rates of €800 mean potential annual rental income of €40,000+ from seasonal letting, particularly during summer months and winter escapes. Many owners maintain personal use during peak months while capitalizing on rental periods, effectively subsidizing their ownership costs. The established expat community and tourism infrastructure provide consistent demand for quality accommodation. Tax benefits for non-resident property owners and favorable Spanish mortgage terms for foreign buyers further enhance the investment appeal.
conclusion: This exceptional 2-bedroom town house in Pilar de La Horadada represents the perfect convergence of lifestyle aspiration and financial sensibility. At €350,000 with premium specifications, you're acquiring a Mediterranean holiday home 40% cheaper than Spanish island alternatives while gaining access to year-round sunshine, established expat community, excellent healthcare, and legitimate rental income opportunities. Whether you envision summers with family and friends, winter escapes from grey northern climates, or strategic property investment capitalizing on Costa Blanca's 8% annual appreciation, this property delivers authenticity without compromise. The location offers beaches, culture, cuisine, and convenience in equal measure—precisely what discerning holiday home buyers seek. Healthcare, education, shopping, and transport are all excellently served, with English-speaking services and international standards.

healthcare.text: Healthcare quality in this region meets high international standards, providing reassurance for holiday home owners and retirees. The nearest major facility is Torrevieja Hospital (25 minutes), offering full emergency departments, specialist services, and modern diagnostic facilities. Multiple private clinics operate throughout the area with English-speaking doctors specializing in chronic disease management, dermatology, and general practice. Dentistry, optometry, and physiotherapy services are excellent and competitively priced. Pharmacies are conveniently located throughout town, with staff providing advice on common ailments. Many expat residents report healthcare experiences exceeding their home countries at significantly lower cost. EU residents and property owners benefit from reciprocal healthcare agreements.

Local markets operate year-round, offering vegetables, fruits, cheese, and fresh fish at prices significantly lower than northern Europe.

The coastal road is excellent quality. Most journeys to beaches, restaurants, and golf courses involve 15-30 minutes driving.

faqs.question: Les étrangers peuvent-ils acheter un bien immobilier en Espagne ?
faqs.answer: Yes, absolutely. Non-EU and EU citizens have equal rights to purchase Spanish property. The process requires a Spanish tax number (NIE), basic documentation, and typically a local lawyer's assistance. Property ownership by foreigners is straightforward and well-established, with thousands of British, German, and Scandinavian residents owning properties throughout Costa Blanca. No visa requirement exists for property purchase alone.

faqs.question: Quels sont les frais d'achat d'un bien immobilier en Espagne ?
faqs.answer: Beyond the purchase price, budget approximately 8-10% additional costs: 6-7% transfer tax, 1-2% notary and registration fees, and 0.4-0.8% property registration charges. Legal fees for lawyer assistance typically cost €1,000-2,000. These costs are negotiable and often partially covered by sellers in competitive markets. For this €350,000 property, total acquisition costs would approximate €28,000-35,000.

faqs.question: La Costa Blanca est-elle un bon endroit pour acheter un bien immobilier ?
faqs.answer: Costa Blanca represents one of Europe's strongest property markets, with 8% year-on-year appreciation, established expat communities, reliable tourism infrastructure, and excellent lifestyle amenities. The region offers authentic Spanish culture combined with international convenience. Property values continue appreciating, rental income opportunities are legitimate, and weather and healthcare exceed most European alternatives—making it excellent for holiday homes, investment properties, and permanent relocation.

faqs.question: Quel est le coût de la vie sur la Costa Blanca ?
faqs.answer: Living costs are significantly lower than Northern Europe. Groceries average 30-40% less than UK prices; dining out costs €10-15 for quality meals; utilities run €80-120 monthly; and healthcare costs are remarkably affordable. Many retirees and holiday home owners report 40-50% lower annual expenses than equivalent UK lifestyles. Property costs vary by location—Pilar de La Horadada offers better value than major tourist centers while maintaining excellent amenities.

faqs.question: Puis-je obtenir un prêt hypothécaire en Espagne en tant qu'étranger ?
faqs.answer: Yes. Spanish banks offer mortgages to non-resident foreign property buyers, typically providing 60-70% loan-to-value financing at competitive rates (currently 3-4% for fixed-term mortgages). Requirements include proof of income, credit history verification, and a local lawyer. Many British buyers successfully obtain Spanish mortgages; some prefer purchasing outright given favorable pricing. Mortgage advisors specializing in Spanish property lending can guide the application process.

faqs.question: À quelle distance se trouve la Costa Blanca de la France ?
faqs.answer: Alicante-Elche Airport, just 50 minutes from Pilar de La Horadada, offers direct flights to UK destinations (London, Manchester, Birmingham, Edinburgh) with flight times of approximately 2.5 hours. Multiple airlines provide daily service with competitive fares, making weekend visits and frequent travel straightforward. Ferry options from southern Spain reach UK in 24-36 hours for those preferring alternative travel methods.

faqs.question: Quel temps fait-il sur la Costa Blanca ?
faqs.answer: Costa Blanca enjoys 320 sunshine days annually with average temperatures of 17°C winter and 28°C summer. Winters are mild—rarely dropping below 10°C—making December through February perfect for escaping grey northern climates. Summers are hot and dry with occasional Mediterranean breezes providing natural cooling. Rainfall is minimal (200mm annually), primarily concentrated in autumn. The climate is consistently described as Mediterranean perfect by residents.
